description: Probably of North Germanic origin: compare Danish slumpe (“to stumble upon by chance”), Norwegian slumpe (“happen by chance”), Swedish slumpa (“to sell off”). Compare also German schlumpen (“to trail; draggle; be sloppy”).

definitionGroups.group: A heavy or helpless collapse; a slouching or drooping posture; a period of poor activity or performance, especially an extended period.

entries.meaning: (slang by extension) A period when a person goes without the expected amount of sex or dating.
examples: TOM. We haven't had sex with each other in five months.
MICHAEL. We're in a slump, I know that."

entries.meaning: A measure of the fluidity of freshly mixed concrete, based on how much the concrete formed in a standard slump cone sags when the cone is removed.
(Scotland) The noise made by anything falling into a hole, or into a soft, miry place.
(Scotland) The gross amount; the mass; the lump.
A cobbler-like dessert cooked on a stove.

verbs.description: slump (third-person singular simple present slumps, present participle slumping, simple past and past participle slumped)

examples: Exhausted, he slumped down onto the sofa.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To decline or fall off in activity or performance.
examples: Real estate prices slumped during the recession.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To lump; to throw together messily.
examples: These different groups […] are exclusively slumped together under that sense.

entries.meaning: To fall or sink suddenly through or in, when walking on a surface, as on thawing snow or ice, a bog, etc.
(transitive, slang) To cause to collapse; to hit hard; to render unsconscious; to kill.
